VOL. XXIV, NO. 18.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 2, 1920.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MAY HAVE DORMITORY IN YEAR

ARMORY MEET GREAT SUCCESS

LITERARY CLUB TO GIVE PLAY

ST. JOHNS BOWS TO HOPKINS

$200,000 Subscribed— Chairman of
Dormitory Committee Thinks That
Building May Be Ready by
Next Term.

Reed of Yale Wins'Varsity Club Special
—Princeton Lands Open Team
Trophy and Georgetown Wins
South Atlantics.

Dr. Bright to Give Address on "The
Art of Expression" on March 10th
--Emmart to Read Paper on
March the 5th.

Cadets are Downed by Black and Blue
Basketeers to Tune of 23 to 13—
Weiner Stars for Hopkins.

The proposed new dormitory
for Johns Hopkins no longer
seems to be merely a possibility,
but has become almost a certainty. It was estimated that the new
building would cost approximately $300,000. Of this amount, the
sum of $200,000 has already been
subscribed. The results thus far
have fulfilled the hopes and expectations of the campaign committee. They had planned to
raise $200,000 from the alumni
and students, and then use this
example of spirit and unselfishness as an argument to induce
some of Hopkins' wealthier
friends to contribute the remaining $100,000. The amount subscribed represents the gifts of the
alumni of moderate means. Sixty
per cent, of all the men who received their degrees at Hopkins
have contributed.
The $200,000 mark was reached
at the Alumni Association's banquet, held recently at the Southern
Hotel. On this occasion $45,000
was raised. Dr. Herbert Friedenwald, '90, and W. Stuart Symington,' 91, subscribed liberally. Both
of these men made informal addresses in behalf of the dormitory
fund.
A luncheon was held at the Merchants' Club last Saturday, at
which the Dormitory Committee
reviewed the situation in regard
to raising the final $100,000. Mr.
George L. Radcliffe, the chairman
of the committee, thinks that
work can be begun on this building in time to have it finished by
the opening of the University in
October.
$45,000 Raised at Banquet.

The Johns Hopkins Alumni Association held a banquet at the
Southern Hotel on Monday evening, February 23. Mr. George L.
Radcliffe, formerly president of
the association, was toastmaster.
The speakers were: Governor
Ritchie, '96; Dr. Hugh H. Young,
President Goodnow, Sir Arthur
Newsholme and Mr. George W.
Knapp, '99. Mr. Knapp was recently elected president of the
association for the coming term.
Several informal speeches on the
dormitory campaign were made by
prominent alumni, including Dr.
Herbert Friedenwald,'90, and W.
Stuart Symington, '91. It was
mainly through the effort of these
men that $45,000 was subscribed
at this gathering: The banquet
was characterized by much "pep"
and enthusiasm.

Before a crowd much larger
than those of previous years, and
with a record entry list of athletes, representing the leading
schools,colleges and universities of
the country, the fifteenth annual
Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment indoor games were held last Saturday night at the Fifth Regiment
Armory. Princeton, represented
by such men as Penfield, Lourie,
Massey and Murray, had the
honor of winning the team trophy,
with 25 points; while the Meadowbrook Club, of Philadelphia, was
second, with 19, and the University of Virginia was third, with
17. Hopkins got only one point.
In the South Atlantic collegiate
events, Georgetown was easily victor, taking 30 points. Hopkins
was fourth, with four.
Undoubtedly, the feature event
of the evening was the 'Varsity
Club 1,000-yard special invitation
race. This, soon after the start,
developed into almost a dead heat
between Reed, of Yale, and Crawford, of Lafayette. The former
was in the lead at the beginning
of the home stretch, but seemed to
be tiring, when the Lafayette man,
with a sudden burst of speed, came
alongside of him, and seemed
about to pass. Becoming desperate, Reed made a last great effort,
and broke the tape an inch ahead.
Irwin, of Penn, was third. This
race was by far the most thrilling
of the meet; the spectators were
on their feet from start to finish,
and cheer after cheer rang out as
first one man and then another
gained a few feet.
Clarence Wheelwright, representing Gilman, pulled a surprise
by winning the open 220-yard dash
from a field of older and mOre experienced runners.
Connolly, of Georgetown, had
little difficulty in winning the

Arthur Emmart will speak on
"John M. Synge, the Irish Poet,"
at the regular meeting of the Literary Club, on Friday evening,
March 5, in the Hopkins Club, at
8 o'clock. All -those who heard
Ernmart's previous paper will
surely be present to enjoy his
forthcoming talk.
The third of a series of public
lectures, under the auspices of the
club, will take place on Wednesday afternoon, March 10, in the
Civil Engineering Hall, at 4.15
o'clock. Dr. Bright, who needs
no introduction to Baltimoreans,
will address the club on "The Art
of Expression." It goes without
saying that no more qualified'
speaker for that subject could
have been found. The lecture,
which is open to the public, has
been given much advertisement,
and a large audience is expected.
Since the Literary Club has no
means of financial support, other
than the dues contributed by members, and since this amount proves
inadequate for securing out-oftown speakers, the club has decided to hold a benefit performance. The play selected is a musical comedy, entitled "Twinkle,
Twinkle," at Ford's Opera House,
on the evening of Thursday,
March 18. The Literary Club
needs the support of the University in this benefit, if any money
is to be realized. Let every fellow
be there, and may his "fair one"
not be lacking. Tickets may be
had from Reuben Foster or any
member of the club. Buy early,
and exchange tickets for the best
seats on or after March 9.
South Atlantic mile by about 30
yards. "Reds" Mullikin, of Hopkins, stepped into the limelight
and took second place from Fitzgerald, also of Georgetown. For
six laps he had run along at an

The Johns Hopkins basketeers
avenged their baseball and football brothers last Friday night,
when they romped away with the
fray with St. John's, 23 to 13. The
local boys leaped to the fore with
the whistle, and had no trouble in
retaining this advantage.
Capt. "Joe" Weiner's clever
dribbling and dodge-work was the
feature of the evening's entertainment. Time and again he
squirmed his way through the
whole Orange and Black five, now
to score a difficult basket and
again to shoot the leather to
"Dutch" Scheurich or "Joe" Cuneo, waiting under the net. The
teamwork of the entire quint
was a vast improvement on that
exhibited on the armory floor in
the last few games. Long shooting was lessened to a considerable
degree, although Cuneo was unable to resist the impulse on several occasions to let fire at long
range.
As is witnessed by the number
of fouls called, the game was
rather rough, but hard, clean play
was everywhere in evidence. Both
teams were fighting with every
ounce of strength,;the Black and
Blue determined to win and the
Cadets, fighting with their backs
to the wall, refused to yield an
inch. The outcome, however, was
a foregone conclusion after the
first skirmish, for the ball was
almost entirely flying around between Hopkins players.
The guarding of the local basket
was of a superb nature. Only
three times were the visitors successful in penetrating the defense
and in finding the range of the
ring—twice in the first and once
in the second period. The credit
for this must go, in large measure,
to "Bill" Wood, although "Joe"
Cuneo and "Lefty" Flinn had a
hand in the watch-dog act.

The Graduate Chemistry Department has grown to such proportions as to warrant the adoption of self-government among the
graduate students who are studying in the chemistry laboratories
opposite the site of McCoy Hall.
Recently the Student Council of
the Graduate Department of
Chemistry was created. It consists of Dr. C. H. Milligan, chairman, and of four other representatives from the various classes—
Messrs. E. 0. Holmes, C. M. Mackall, W. R. Norris and J. E. Sharp.
It will act as the judiciary and
executive body in all cases of violation of the honor system in the
ranks of the graduate students.
In this respect it is similar to the
undergraduate Student Council.
As the official link between the
chemistry faculty and the graduate students whom it represents,
the Council will have an advisory
character in matters pertaining to
the general welfdre of the department.

Soph Class Meeting.

At a meeting of the Sophomore
Class last Thursday the newly
elected honorary president gave
his "fellow classmen" a very interesting address. Dr. Mitchell expressed his appreciation of his
election to the post of honorary
president, and continued with the
expression of his wish to foster
the right relation between teacher
and pupil—a relation which the
teacher finds a hard one to maintain, for he cannot be too advancedly friendly with or hold
aloof to too great an extent from
his pupils without endangering
the loss of the very friendship
which he seeks. Dr. Mitchell also
discussed the honor system at the
University.
The question of having an indoor track meet with the freshmen on the following Monday was
discussed and on account of the
short notice decided negatively,
but a challenge was issued for an
outdoor track meet-between'22 and
'23 at some date far enough ahead
to permit a sufficient amount of
practice. The report on excuses of
the Committee on Absences was
followed by a criticism of the seemingly undue severity of the committee in not excusing certain absentees. Messrs. Hensel and Cotton urged the necessity of attendance to duty of those sophomores
assigned to paddling work of the
wegulation kind.
The following men were elected
to membership in the class: De
Forse, Justice, Price, Robinson,
Warren, Wilkinson and Zeskind.

MAR. 2, 1920

A Reply to Mr. Hamburger.

Every progressive and broadminded man will always welcome
helpful, constructive criticism,
even if it is adverse and sometimes painful. No one, we hope,
will oppose us in the declaration
that it is the duty of every fullblooded Hopkins man to uphold
our University and any of its organizations in every case of unfair and unwarranted criticism.
1 We are unreservedly opposed to
any form of mud-slinging against
our institutions, regardless of
whether the narrow-minded criticism is aimed at anything connected with Johns Hopkins or at
any other educational institution.
Admiral William S. Sims, orator at the University Day exercises
of the University of Pennsylvania,
criticized the tendency of Americans to resent adverse comment
upon anything American, even
when the pointing to errors is constructive. We agree with him,
and the "Mail Bag" gives the students the necessary opportunity
for setting forth their views in
matters pertaining to our University life.
We confess ignorance as to the
official causes which led to the ac-

ceptance of the resignation of one
of our ablest and most popular instructors. We are sure, however,
that Hopkins is not dying of dry
rot. The loss of one member of
the faculty, or even of several members, is not an index of retrogression.
In reply to Mr. Hamburger, we
direct his attention to the fact
that most of the universities
throughout the United States suffer the annual loss of some of
their old professors. If this fact
applied only to the Johns Hopkins
University, we would not hesitate
to agree with him. Both President Goodnow and the Hon. Mr.
Hoover pointed out the defects
of the present educational system throughout this country. We
are not surprised, therefore, that
under present conditions, many
professors can command in the
business world double or even
triple the salary they now receive.
"This day you are taking the
vow of financial chastity!" prophesied Dr. Maurice Bloomfield in a
certain Commencement Day address to a group of men upon
whom were conferred their Ph. D.
degrees. How many professors
have faithfully kept this vow?
When a professor finds that he is
unreasonably underpaid, it is not
contrary to human nature for him
to forsake academic life for business life. It is only when the professor is adequately paid and then
quits that he has broken his vow.
We commend the interest of Mr.
Hamburger in the affairs of his
Alma Mater, but we deplore his
statement that Hopkins is dying
of dry rot. Just criticism is helpful, and we would like to see more
of it. Let the critic first get the
facts, be sure that there is foundation for criticism, and then express his views in a rational
manner.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 2, 1920.

6

DEBATING TRIANGLE FORMED
Washington and Lee Takes Place of
Virginia, and Will Meet North Carolina at Homewood on May 1st.

After lengthy negotiations and
an effort to meet the rather contradictory and unintelligible demands of Virginia, Hopkins has
finally arranged a new debating
triangle with Washington and
Lee University and North Carolina, to take the place of the old
triangle composed of North Carolina, Virginia and Hopkins. The
day for the contest has been set
for May 1, when the Hopkins affirmative team will travel to
Chapel Hill and the negative team
to Lexington, Va., to defend our
University in the enemies' territory. North Carolina will meet •
Washington and Lee's representatives at Homewood. As old followers of Hopkins debating will
recognize, this policy is a reversion to the old policy of the triangle previous to the innovation
of last year, by which one team
stayed home while the other
travelled.
The subject for this year, "Resolved, that a system of universal,
compulsory military training
should be adopted for the United
States," is, to say the least, a very
practical one. It is one in which
everyone is deeply interested because we realize that a decision
must soon be made that may affect our whole national policy.
Those who attend the contest in
the Civil Engineering Building on
May 1 will therefore not only hear
a real live discussion, but may
gain some pointers that will help
them to vote intelligently on the
subject when the time comes.

THE TURKISH CIGARETTE
You may hunt the
world over—but you cannot find a cigarette to
take the place of Murad.
The tobacco in Murad is 100% pure
Turkish—and Turkish is the most
famous of all tobaccos for cigarettes.
It is true that "ordinary" cigarettes
cost a trifle less.

R. 0. T. C.

The Department of Military
Science and Tactics announces
the arrival of complete infantry
field equipment. This includes
scientific packs, etc. In March
the entire R. 0. T. C. unit at the
University will be given two
weeks of outdoor instruction in
order to instruct thoroughly in
the infantry drill regulations recently issued.
A large amount of time in the
spring will be devoted to target
practice. The Military Department has 30,000 rounds of gallerypractice ammunition and a supply of .22 calibre rifles is on the
way. These will be used on the
range in the basement of the Civil
Engineering Building.
Some time in March, all the
professors of military science and
tactics at eastern universities will
meet in Washington to formulate
a definite R. 0. T. C. policy for
the future, and to better the
courses by an exchange of views.

The research facilities of the General Electric Company
are an asset of world-wide importance, as recent war
work has so clearly demonstrated. Their advantages
in pursuits of peace made !them of inestimable value
in time of war.
A most interesting story tells of the devices evolved which substantially aided in solving one of the most pressing problems of
the war—the submarine menace. Fanciful, but no less real, were
the results attained in radio communication which enabled an
aviator to control a fleet of flying battleships, and made possible
the sending, without a wire, history-making messages and orders
to ships at sea. Scarcely less important was the X-ray tube,
specially designed for field hospital use and a notable contributiotho
the military surgical service.And many other products,for both corn baton t and industrial use, did their full share in secui ing the victory.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 2, 1920.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MAY HAVE DORMITORY IN YEAR

ARMORY MEET GREAT SUCCESS

LITERARY CLUB TO GIVE PLAY

ST. JOHNS BOWS TO HOPKINS

$200,000 Subscribed— Chairman of
Dormitory Committee Thinks That
Building May Be Ready by
Next Term.

Reed of Yale Wins'Varsity Club Special
—Princeton Lands Open Team
Trophy and Georgetown Wins
South Atlantics.

Dr. Bright to Give Address on "The
Art of Expression" on March 10th
--Emmart to Read Paper on
March the 5th.

Cadets are Downed by Black and Blue
Basketeers to Tune of 23 to 13—
Weiner Stars for Hopkins.

The proposed new dormitory
for Johns Hopkins no longer
seems to be merely a possibility,
but has become almost a certainty. It was estimated that the new
building would cost approximately $300,000. Of this amount, the
sum of $200,000 has already been
subscribed. The results thus far
have fulfilled the hopes and expectations of the campaign committee. They had planned to
raise $200,000 from the alumni
and students, and then use this
example of spirit and unselfishness as an argument to induce
some of Hopkins' wealthier
friends to contribute the remaining $100,000. The amount subscribed represents the gifts of the
alumni of moderate means. Sixty
per cent, of all the men who received their degrees at Hopkins
have contributed.
The $200,000 mark was reached
at the Alumni Association's banquet, held recently at the Southern
Hotel. On this occasion $45,000
was raised. Dr. Herbert Friedenwald, '90, and W. Stuart Symington,' 91, subscribed liberally. Both
of these men made informal addresses in behalf of the dormitory
fund.
A luncheon was held at the Merchants' Club last Saturday, at
which the Dormitory Committee
reviewed the situation in regard
to raising the final $100,000. Mr.
George L. Radcliffe, the chairman
of the committee, thinks that
work can be begun on this building in time to have it finished by
the opening of the University in
October.
$45,000 Raised at Banquet.

The Johns Hopkins Alumni Association held a banquet at the
Southern Hotel on Monday evening, February 23. Mr. George L.
Radcliffe, formerly president of
the association, was toastmaster.
The speakers were: Governor
Ritchie, '96; Dr. Hugh H. Young,
President Goodnow, Sir Arthur
Newsholme and Mr. George W.
Knapp, '99. Mr. Knapp was recently elected president of the
association for the coming term.
Several informal speeches on the
dormitory campaign were made by
prominent alumni, including Dr.
Herbert Friedenwald,'90, and W.
Stuart Symington, '91. It was
mainly through the effort of these
men that $45,000 was subscribed
at this gathering: The banquet
was characterized by much "pep"
and enthusiasm.

Before a crowd much larger
than those of previous years, and
with a record entry list of athletes, representing the leading
schools,colleges and universities of
the country, the fifteenth annual
Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment indoor games were held last Saturday night at the Fifth Regiment
Armory. Princeton, represented
by such men as Penfield, Lourie,
Massey and Murray, had the
honor of winning the team trophy,
with 25 points; while the Meadowbrook Club, of Philadelphia, was
second, with 19, and the University of Virginia was third, with
17. Hopkins got only one point.
In the South Atlantic collegiate
events, Georgetown was easily victor, taking 30 points. Hopkins
was fourth, with four.
Undoubtedly, the feature event
of the evening was the 'Varsity
Club 1,000-yard special invitation
race. This, soon after the start,
developed into almost a dead heat
between Reed, of Yale, and Crawford, of Lafayette. The former
was in the lead at the beginning
of the home stretch, but seemed to
be tiring, when the Lafayette man,
with a sudden burst of speed, came
alongside of him, and seemed
about to pass. Becoming desperate, Reed made a last great effort,
and broke the tape an inch ahead.
Irwin, of Penn, was third. This
race was by far the most thrilling
of the meet; the spectators were
on their feet from start to finish,
and cheer after cheer rang out as
first one man and then another
gained a few feet.
Clarence Wheelwright, representing Gilman, pulled a surprise

Arthur Emmart will speak on
"John M. Synge, the Irish Poet,"
at the regular meeting of the Literary Club, on Friday evening,
March 5, in the Hopkins Club, at
8 o'clock. All -those who heard
Ernmart's previous paper will
surely be present to enjoy his
forthcoming talk.
The third of a series of public
lectures, under the auspices of the
club, will take place on Wednesday afternoon, March 10, in the
Civil Engineering Hall, at 4.15
o'clock. Dr. Bright, who needs
no introduction to Baltimoreans,
will address the club on "The Art
of Expression." It goes without
saying that no more qualified'
speaker for that subject could
have been found. The lecture,
which is open to the public, has
been given much advertisement,
and a large audience is expected.
Since the Literary Club has no
means of financial support, other
than the dues contributed by members, and since this amount proves
inadequate for securing out-oftown speakers, the club has decided to hold a benefit performance. The play selected is a musical comedy, entitled "Twinkle,
Twinkle," at Ford's Opera House,
on the evening of Thursday,
March 18. The Literary Club
needs the support of the University in this benefit, if any money
is to be realized. Let every fellow
be there, and may his "fair one"
not be lacking. Tickets may be
had from Reuben Foster or any
member of the club. Buy early,
and exchange tickets for the best
seats on or after March 9.

The Johns Hopkins basketeers
avenged their baseball and football brothers last Friday night,
when they romped away with the
fray with St. John's, 23 to 13. The
local boys leaped to the fore with
the whistle, and had no trouble in
retaining this advantage.
Capt. "Joe" Weiner's clever
dribbling and dodge-work was the
feature of the evening's entertainment. Time and again he
squirmed his way through the
whole Orange and Black five, now
to score a difficult basket and
again to shoot the leather to
"Dutch" Scheurich or "Joe" Cuneo, waiting under the net. The
teamwork of the entire quint
was a vast improvement on that
exhibited on the armory floor in
the last few games. Long shooting was lessened to a considerable
degree, although Cuneo was unable to resist the impulse on several occasions to let fire at long
range.
As is witnessed by the number
of fouls called, the game was
rather rough, but hard, clean play
was everywhere in evidence. Both
teams were fighting with every
ounce of strength,;the Black and
Blue determined to win and the
Cadets, fighting with their backs
to the wall, refused to yield an
inch. The outcome, however, was
a foregone conclusion after the
first skirmish, for the ball was
almost entirely flying around between Hopkins players.
The guarding of the local basket
was of a superb nature. Only
three times were the visitors successful in penetrating the defense
and in finding the range of the
ring—twice in the first and once
in the second period. The credit
for this must go, in large measure,
to "Bill" Wood, although "Joe"
Cuneo and "Lefty" Flinn had a
hand in the watch-dog act.

The Graduate Chemistry Department has grown to such proportions as to warrant the adoption of self-government among the
graduate students who are studying in the chemistry laboratories
opposite the site of McCoy Hall.
Recently the Student Council of
the Graduate Department of
Chemistry was created. It consists of Dr. C. H. Milligan, chairman, and of four other representatives from the various classes—
Messrs. E. 0. Holmes, C. M. Mackall, W. R. Norris and J. E. Sharp.
It will act as the judiciary and
executive body in all cases of violation of the honor system in the
ranks of the graduate students.
In this respect it is similar to the
undergraduate Student Council.
As the official link between the
chemistry faculty and the graduate students whom it represents,
the Council will have an advisory
character in matters pertaining to
the general welfdre of the department.

Soph Class Meeting.

At a meeting of the Sophomore
Class last Thursday the newly
elected honorary president gave
his "fellow classmen" a very interesting address. Dr. Mitchell expressed his appreciation of his
election to the post of honorary
president, and continued with the
expression of his wish to foster
the right relation between teacher
and pupil—a relation which the
teacher finds a hard one to maintain, for he cannot be too advancedly friendly with or hold
aloof to too great an extent from
his pupils without endangering
the loss of the very friendship
which he seeks. Dr. Mitchell also
discussed the honor system at the
University.
The question of having an indoor track meet with the freshmen on the following Monday was
discussed and on account of the
short notice decided negatively,
but a challenge was issued for an
outdoor track meet-between'22 and
'23 at some date far enough ahead
to permit a sufficient amount of
practice. The report on excuses of
the Committee on Absences was
followed by a criticism of the seemingly undue severity of the committee in not excusing certain absentees. Messrs. Hensel and Cotton urged the necessity of attendance to duty of those sophomores
assigned to paddling work of the
wegulation kind.
The following men were elected
to membership in the class: De
Forse, Justice, Price, Robinson,
Warren, Wilkinson and Zeskind.

MAR. 2, 1920

A Reply to Mr. Hamburger.

Every progressive and broadminded man will always welcome
helpful, constructive criticism,
even if it is adverse and sometimes painful. No one, we hope,
will oppose us in the declaration
that it is the duty of every fullblooded Hopkins man to uphold
our University and any of its organizations in every case of unfair and unwarranted criticism.
1 We are unreservedly opposed to
any form of mud-slinging against
our institutions, regardless of
whether the narrow-minded criticism is aimed at anything connected with Johns Hopkins or at
any other educational institution.
Admiral William S. Sims, orator at the University Day exercises
of the University of Pennsylvania,
criticized the tendency of Americans to resent adverse comment
upon anything American, even
when the pointing to errors is constructive. We agree with him,
and the "Mail Bag" gives the students the necessary opportunity
for setting forth their views in
matters pertaining to our University life.
We confess ignorance as to the
official causes which led to the ac-

ceptance of the resignation of one
of our ablest and most popular instructors. We are sure, however,
that Hopkins is not dying of dry
rot. The loss of one member of
the faculty, or even of several members, is not an index of retrogression.
In reply to Mr. Hamburger, we
direct his attention to the fact
that most of the universities
throughout the United States suffer the annual loss of some of
their old professors. If this fact
applied only to the Johns Hopkins
University, we would not hesitate
to agree with him. Both President Goodnow and the Hon. Mr.
Hoover pointed out the defects
of the present educational system throughout this country. We
are not surprised, therefore, that
under present conditions, many
professors can command in the
business world double or even
triple the salary they now receive.
"This day you are taking the
vow of financial chastity!" prophesied Dr. Maurice Bloomfield in a
certain Commencement Day address to a group of men upon
whom were conferred their Ph. D.
degrees. How many professors
have faithfully kept this vow?
When a professor finds that he is
unreasonably underpaid, it is not
contrary to human nature for him
to forsake academic life for business life. It is only when the professor is adequately paid and then
quits that he has broken his vow.
We commend the interest of Mr.
Hamburger in the affairs of his
Alma Mater, but we deplore his
statement that Hopkins is dying
of dry rot. Just criticism is helpful, and we would like to see more
of it. Let the critic first get the
facts, be sure that there is foundation for criticism, and then express his views in a rational
manner.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 2, 1920.

6

DEBATING TRIANGLE FORMED
Washington and Lee Takes Place of
Virginia, and Will Meet North Carolina at Homewood on May 1st.

After lengthy negotiations and
an effort to meet the rather contradictory and unintelligible demands of Virginia, Hopkins has
finally arranged a new debating
triangle with Washington and
Lee University and North Carolina, to take the place of the old
triangle composed of North Carolina, Virginia and Hopkins. The
day for the contest has been set
for May 1, when the Hopkins affirmative team will travel to
Chapel Hill and the negative team
to Lexington, Va., to defend our
University in the enemies' territory. North Carolina will meet •
Washington and Lee's representatives at Homewood. As old followers of Hopkins debating will
recognize, this policy is a reversion to the old policy of the triangle previous to the innovation
of last year, by which one team
stayed home while the other
travelled.
The subject for this year, "Resolved, that a system of universal,
compulsory military training
should be adopted for the United
States," is, to say the least, a very
practical one. It is one in which
everyone is deeply interested because we realize that a decision
must soon be made that may affect our whole national policy.
Those who attend the contest in
the Civil Engineering Building on
May 1 will therefore not only hear
a real live discussion, but may
gain some pointers that will help
them to vote intelligently on the
subject when the time comes.

THE TURKISH CIGARETTE
You may hunt the
world over—but you cannot find a cigarette to
take the place of Murad.
The tobacco in Murad is 100% pure
Turkish—and Turkish is the most
famous of all tobaccos for cigarettes.
It is true that "ordinary" cigarettes
cost a trifle less.

R. 0. T. C.

The Department of Military
Science and Tactics announces
the arrival of complete infantry
field equipment. This includes
scientific packs, etc. In March
the entire R. 0. T. C. unit at the
University will be given two
weeks of outdoor instruction in
order to instruct thoroughly in
the infantry drill regulations recently issued.
A large amount of time in the
spring will be devoted to target
practice. The Military Department has 30,000 rounds of gallerypractice ammunition and a supply of .22 calibre rifles is on the
way. These will be used on the
range in the basement of the Civil
Engineering Building.
Some time in March, all the
professors of military science and
tactics at eastern universities will
meet in Washington to formulate
a definite R. 0. T. C. policy for
the future, and to better the
courses by an exchange of views.

The research facilities of the General Electric Company
are an asset of world-wide importance, as recent war
work has so clearly demonstrated. Their advantages
in pursuits of peace made !them of inestimable value
in time of war.
A most interesting story tells of the devices evolved which substantially aided in solving one of the most pressing problems of
the war—the submarine menace. Fanciful, but no less real, were
the results attained in radio communication which enabled an
aviator to control a fleet of flying battleships, and made possible
the sending, without a wire, history-making messages and orders
to ships at sea. Scarcely less important was the X-ray tube,
specially designed for field hospital use and a notable contributiotho
the military surgical service.And many other products,for both corn baton t and industrial use, did their full share in secui ing the victory.
